Blighting Effect

Chapter IV discussed at some length the ways in which an express-
way could have a blighting effect upon adjacent areas and these ways are
grouped into five categories in Chapter V. Since in this Chapter we are
engaged in a comparison of two routes the discussion which follows does
not relate to the sections which are identical.

1. Extent to Which Each Route Splits Established Residential Areas:
The Northern Route clearly splits the Mt. Vernon area in two.
While the large residential area in East Baltimore between Green-
mount Avenue and Linwood Avenue does not have quite the same
sense of well established neighborhood identity as does the Mt.
Vernon area, the Northern Routes goes plowing through this sec-
tion with minimum adherence to any kind of neighborhood
boundary. At no point does the Harbor Route split an established
residential area.

2. Extent to Which Each Route Separates Areas Which for Eco-
nomic Reasons Should Be in Close Proximity: It appears that
neither route is guilty on this score. In each case there are ample
crossings in any section where crossings would be necessary or
desirable.

3. Proximity to High Grade Residential Areas: The nearest ap-
proach to this condition for either route would be the passage of
the Northern Route through the Mt. Vernon area. While the
extent to which this proximity would be blighting is debatable
there is no similar situation along the Harbor Route.

4. Proximity of Elevated Structures to Any Residential Areas: This
factor does not apply to either route from the point of divergence
to the Jones Falls Expressway, but does occur on each route east
of the Jones Falls Expressway. Along the Harbor Route resi-
